Description: -Either I stay here or I just die.- A resident of the Voronezh region is trying to rescue her husband from an illegal basement in ZaitsevoAs Valentina Avilova from Novovoronezh told ASTRA, her husband Alexey signed a contract and went to war last fall. On August 26, he decided to escape from the unit and return home. He did not tell her the reasons why he did this. He stayed at home for only a few days - soon he was stopped on the street to have his documents checked and taken to the police station. There it turned out that he was wanted.-My husband called me and said that he had been detained, so I accordingly came there. We sat in the police for two hours, the military commandant‚Äôs office arrived. He said: -Guys, I‚Äôm not going anywhere. Either I stay here or I just die.- A scuffle broke out, and eventually he was handcuffed, forced into a car, and taken to the military commandant‚Äôs office. I called the duty officer there, they don‚Äôt provide information - it‚Äôs the weekend. And three days later the prosecutor‚Äôs office told me that he was sent to Zaitsevo,- says Valentina.Valentina says that Alexey left at home all his personal belongings - from a military ID to a telephone, on which his comrades periodically write. Answering them, she found out that some of her husband‚Äôs colleagues also passed through Zaitsevo.-One tells me, I know what kind of place this is, I was there for two weeks. He was put there because he insulted the commander. Why, if my husband broke the law, is he not in a pre-trial detention center, but in a hole? And why are his rights not respected? They should at least have informed me as a relative that my husband was detained under such and such an article, and not torture people and mock me. They are not even allowed to go to the toilet, people walk under themselves. Up to 100 people sit there at a time. You wouldn‚Äôt wish this on your enemy,- Valentina told ASTRA.According to Valentina, her husband went to war not out of patriotic convictions or for the sake of money, but because -he was interested in - - he did not serve in military service for medical reasons. - When he made his choice, it was a shock for me. And they don‚Äôt even have this money, because they provided for themselves. They bought socks, tents, food, cigarettes, some tools, pens, paid for their communications, the Internet. We bought tents so that we wouldn‚Äôt sleep on the cold ground. I think this is not normal. Why did they go to fight then? They, like patriots, went for Russia. What did you get in the end? Such an appeal? What money? What is shown on TV is all nonsense,- says Valentina.Valentina has sent appeals to the presidential administration, as well as to several deputies, but is worried that the answer to them will not arrive on time , and now -every minute counts.--I just need to get my husband out of there. Let him be punished according to the law, they will give him a prison term, but he did not deserve what is happening in Zaitsevo. I don't think anyone deserves this. I owe my husband my whole life, I cannot leave him. I've known him for over 20 years. I‚Äôm ready to do anything for him, but he needs to be pulled back out of this hole. And I don‚Äôt even know if he‚Äôs alive or not. My head is just a mess. But I won‚Äôt forgive myself if I don‚Äôt help him,- says Valentina. Throughout the entire full-scale war, ASTRA talks about illegal prisons for -refuseniks-, where military personnel i>threatsandvarious torturedforced into deadly assaults. Description: ASTRA: Kadyrovites opened fire in the center of Valuyki, Belgorod region. A video appeared on the Internet in which a man in civilian clothes fires a burst of pistol into the sky and dances Lezginka surrounded by other men in military uniform. As the publication -Ashes- writes... A Chechen from Akhmat threw a grenade at the car of a military man from Dagestan in the Belgorod region 35-year-old Kurban Akaev is the commander of a repair company from the 752nd regiment, which is based in the city of Valuiki. Kurban is Dargin by origin. When asked by an ASTRA correspondent whether his nationality is the cause of the conflict, Kurban replies-I didn‚Äôt have any conflict with him.- On the night of September 29, Kurban's vacation began. He met him at the Roly-Poly cafe in Valuyki, chatting in a company of about a dozen friends near his Toyota Camry. Police officers and a company of about 20 Chechens stood nearby. According to Kurban, before the flash he heard someone pulling the pin from a grenade. -It[the grenade] rolled a little and suddenly exploded. An officer stood next to me - he bent over. I see he‚Äôs bleeding from his head because of the fragments.- The wounded officer, says Kurban, was afraid to go to the hospital so that his unit would not accuse him of being AWOL. According to Kurban, the military man who attacked him serves in the Akhmat regiment -When he threw a grenade, panic set in, people began to run inside and he shouted ‚ÄòAkhmat strength‚Äô. He raised his hand and I recognized him immediately,- says Kurban. As a result of the explosion, his car was scratched many times by shrapnel, and in one place his door was broken.When asked whether the grenade was a live one, Kurban answers in the affirmative. The owner of the Roly-Poly cafe, in a conversation with ASTRA, suggested that the grenade could have been a -dummy-, since there was no serious damage as a result of the explosion and there was no need to call an ambulance. Kurban says that the Chechen who attacked him was together with two other people. Chechens from a company of 20 people approached him after the explosion to discuss car repairs. -They came running, shouting that he would do [repair] your car <..> Then they got into a fight. An innocent man stood with a phone and talked - and they attacked him, they thought that he was filming them,- says the military man. According to Kurban, the Chechens have long been -lawless- in Valuyki. In July, in this city, soldiers from Chechnya danced lezginka and shot in the air - after which the head of the district said that -measures have been taken to prevent such cases.- This is not the first time that Cafe Roly-Poly has been in the news: in March, residents of Valuyka they called for it to be closedbecause of two strippers who washed each other during the performance.

Description: A Holocaust memorial ceremony was banned in St. Petersburg. At the same time, the first funeral ceremony in memory of Jewish victims of Nazism took place at the monument. According to media publications and photographs in the group of the Jewish Community Center of St. Petersburg, since then the ceremony has been held annually. Even the Covid year 2020 was no exception - when quarantine restrictions in Russia were most actively enforced.This year, the administration of the Pushkin district of St. Petersburg refused to approve the ceremony at the -Formula of Sorrow-. A photo of the refusal to approve the event was published today by the Jewish Community Center. The reason given by officials is to combat the coronavirus. This year -The public ceremony will not take place, but everyone who considers it important for themselves to honor the memory of the Jews of the city of Pushkin who fell victims of the Nazi genocide can independently come to the -Formula of Sorrow- monument at any time 6 October, on the anniversary of the tragic events of 1941,- the Jewish Community Center reports on social networks St. Petersburg.

Title: üñº -They were aware of the planned murder and agreed to participa...
Description: -They were aware of the planned murder and agreed to participate in it.- ASTRA publishes a fragment from the decision to initiate the first known criminal case of the mass murder of Russian military personnel by its own command in the war in UkraineIn March 2024, the Main Military Investigation Department of the Investigative Committee in Lugansk opened a criminal case against the leadership  6th Motorized Rifle Division. This military formation was formed in 2022 and consists mainly of mobilized people. His command is accused of torturing their own military personnel - as well as their mass murder.The murder of 7 military personnel took place in the early morning of July 4, 2023 in the village of Bakhmutskoye, the so-called -DPR-. At that time, battles were still going on for this village - which the military from the 6th division took advantage of. They took their colleagues to the basement and threw 5 F-1 grenades there. The survivors of the explosion were finished off with a silent PB pistol. 19 Russian military personnel are listed as victims in the case. All of them were held at different times in the basements of apartment buildings in the city of Popasnaya -LPR-. According to the command, they were placed there for refusing to follow orders. There they were subjected to torture: they were beaten -with their feet, fists, and also with various objects and special equipment in the face and body.- The military was also denied access to food, water and hygiene products. Out of 19 victims, military prosecutors -saved- 8 people by dismissing the military personnel. Another military man escaped execution in Bakhmutskoye due to injury. For the first time, a criminal case against the command of the 6th division became known this summer from investigations of the Ukrainian portal -Suspilne-. The publication confirmed information about the criminal case in conversations with relatives of the murdered and murderers. To them, Ukrainian journalists introduced themselves as employees of -public television,- without specifying either the TV channel or the country of broadcasting. Among others, -Suspilna- was able to reach the wife of the commander of the 6th division, Marat Ospanov (call sign -Gyurza- - in the photo), whom investigators consider the main organizer of the massacre. This summer, his wife told reporters that Ospanov was being examined at a psychiatric clinic in Lugansk. According to Suspilne, 19 soldiers from the 6th division were sent to torture cellars in the city of Popasnaya due to publications on social networks of complaints about the conditions of service. ASTRA was among the first to publish these appeals from the military of the 6th division - for example, the complaint of those mobilized from the 1307th regiment that they were being used as -cannon fodder-. 5 of the 7 soldiers killed in Bakhmutsky served in this regiment.In total, there are 7 defendants in the criminal case. As ASTRA found out, the case was initiated under articles of abuse of power (parts 3 and 4 of article 286), unlawful deprivation of liberty (part 3 of article 127) and murder of two or more persons (part 2 of article 105).

Description: ASTRA: -If a person survives for six months, he will receive money, if not, he will receive nothing.- The Russian military is paid several times less than promised, while they are forced to storm positions in Ukraine with injuries. A fighter with the call sign -Johnny- (in the first photo) told ASTRA... The Russian Ministry of Defense does not conclude contracts with prisoners, but draws up -written consents-. Because of this, pardoned prisoners receive lower salaries and are not considered combat veteransThe BBC Russian Service writes about this in its investigation, which studied court decisions in the cases of former prisoners, filed lawsuits against the Russian Ministry of Defense. This data proves information previously published by ASTRA from the words of the former prisoners themselves.The BBC claims that those prisoners who agreed to participate in the SVO for the sake of pardon were transferred to the border Rostov colony No. 12 and allowed them to sign a document called -Agreement on voluntary assistance in carrying out tasks assigned to the Armed Forces of the Russian Federation,- which is not considered an ordinary contract with the Ministry of Defense.-This consent is not a contract, providing for the rights and responsibilities of each of the parties,- stated one of the courts in Volgograd.Under these conditions, the Ministry of Defense on the instructions of the Chief of the General Staff Valery Gerasimov, recruited prisoners from February 24 to September 1, 2023. In the fall of 2023, Putin stopped pardoning prisoners‚Äîa law appeared according to which they began to be conditionally released to be sent to the front before the end of the war, as mobilized and contract soldiers. But the pardoned survivors continued to be released home. However, prisoners do not receive social benefits, they are not given the status of combat veterans, and their salary is at least two to four times less than that generally accepted for SVO participants - from 40,500 to 92,000 rubles. Also, for injury, ex-prisoners were entitled to a one-time payment of 50,000 rubles. up to 300,000 rubles, while for ordinary military personnel - 3 million rubles. based on the fact of injury and an additional 3 million in the case where the injury led to dismissal from the service. Description: ASTRA: The suspect in the assassination attempt on Zakhar Prilepin confessed, claims channel 112, owned by the Kremlin Ren-TV. -The man said that he was recruited by one of the Ukrainian special services several years ago. He gave them the information they needed... The accused of the attempt on the life of Zakhar Prilepin is demanded to be sentenced to life imprisonmentAbout this writes -Mediazona- with reference to a correspondent from the hall of the 2nd Western District Military Court.The investigation claims that the accused Alexander Permyakov in 2022 received Ukraine instructions about exploding the car of the writer Zakhar Prilepin and part of the money - two thousand rubles, after which he entered Russia through Latvia and committed an assassination attempt.It is alleged that correspondence with the elder was found on Permyakov‚Äôs phone operative SBU Zhuravkin, with whom Permyakov discussed -the preparation of a terrorist attack, surveillance of Prilepin and his houses, the placement of mines.- From a page on VKontakte under the name Ivanka Polikarpova, Zhuravkin communicated with Prilepin‚Äôs son Ignat and thus found out where the writer would be on the day of the terrorist attack. In addition to a life sentence, the prosecutor's office asks that Permyakov spend the first 10 years of his sentence in prison, and also pay a fine of one and a half million rubles. The prosecutor called the social danger of the crime colossal and noted -strong antisocial attitudes and socially dangerous interests- of the accused. At the same time, Permyakov‚Äôs sister Irina told the investigator during interrogation that while still a schoolchild, her brother was sentenced to 7 years because -he and his friends beat someone.- Four years later, he was released on parole, and in 2015 went -to the DPR militia.- In the spring of 2022, Permyakov moved to the Khmelnitsky region of Ukraine -as a migrant.-Prilepin himself refused to participate in the debate and asked that Permyakov be punished -in accordance with the law.- Permyakov did not speak out in the debate. In May 2023, a bomb was blown up in the Nizhny Novgorod region car by Zakhar Prilepin. As a result, the writer was seriously injured, and his guard Alexander Shubin died on the spot. The Investigative Committee opened a case of terrorism. On the same day, not far from the scene of the assassination attempt, there was detainedAlexander Permyakov. They found on him passports of Russia and Ukraine and a fake passport of Kazakhstan, nearby - a combat pistol with a silencer, a band-aid, five SIM cards, two bank cards, cash rubles and hryvnias, a flashlight, a compass, a flint, and a sheet with ten telephone numbers and names. At the police station, Permyakov admitted to the attempt on Prilepin‚Äôs life, regretting that he did not die.

Description: The mayor of New York was charged with bribery for $100,000. He became the first sitting mayor of the city suspected of a criminal offenseThe US Attorney's Office on September 26 indicted the mayor of New York, representative Democratic Party Eric Adams is accused of receiving illegal campaign donations, as well as Turkey's influence on the election of Adams as head of the city, writes Reuters.Adams is charged with the following: - bribery;- two counts of extorting election contributions from foreign citizens;- organizing a fraudulent bank transfer scheme;- illegally receiving contributions from a foreign citizen for an election campaign.It is alleged that while still the head of Brooklyn, Adams traveled for free on a Turkish plane airlines on a trip costing tens of thousands of dollars, and for two nights in a luxurious suite at the St. Regis in Istanbul paid only $600, although he should have paid about $7,000.New York Federal Prosecutor Damian Williams said that the entire amount of the mayor's Turkish leisure, which included hotel stays, yacht excursions and flights business class, reached about $100,000, and Adams, according to Williams, -was required to declare- all expenses. Williams believes that in this way the Turkish authorities tried to gain the mayor's favor in order to later influence his decisions. In addition, Adams also partially financed his 2021 mayoral campaign in New York with donations from Turkey, receiving them through bogus American citizens. Adams, 64, denies wrongdoing and said he will fight the charges in court. He said he will not resign. -I will continue to do my job as mayor,- he said at a news conference in response to calls to resign.Adams, a former police officer, became the first of 110 mayors of New York who was charged with a criminal offense during his stay.

Description: An installation dedicated to Stanislav Petrov, the man who prevented nuclear war, has appeared in St. PetersburgThe text reads: -The light of the sun's rays reflected from the clouds.- The work is dedicated to the event of 1983: While Petrov was on duty on the night of September 26, 1983, the missile attack warning system in the secret part of Serpukhov-15 in the Moscow region gave a signal - ballistic missiles were launched from US territory rockets. The day before, at a meeting of the Russian Security Council on nuclear deterrence, Vladimir Putin proposed to make changes to the doctrine of nuclear deterrence: -In the updated version of the document, aggression against Russia by any non-nuclear state, but with the participation or support nuclear state is proposed to be considered as their joint attack on Russia.-Photo: -Paper-

Title: üñº A Russian who fled from mobilization was denied political asyl...
Description: A Russian who fled from mobilization was denied political asylum in Norway. The country's authorities referred to Putin's words that the mobilization had ended Pavel Suetin left Severomorsk in the Murmansk region on September 22, 2022 - the day after the mobilization was announced. He came to Norway and requested asylum in the city of Vads√∏. However, in mid-September 2024, the Norwegian Migration Agency informed the man that he was not eligible for asylum and must leave the Schengen area within three weeks. This is the first known decision of this kind in Norway, writes The Barents Observer. According to the migration department, mobilization is not currently being carried out in Russia. Norwegian officials refer to the words of Vladimir Putin and Sergei Shoigu, who announced the completion of mobilization in October 2022. Suetin himself claims that the military commissariat continues to look for him even two years after the start of mobilization. According to the man, people from the military registration and enlistment office came to the apartment where he was registered and asked where he was. Suetin does not yet know what to do if the Norwegian authorities still force him to leave the country. -I'm sure, I know that I will be taken to war. I am of military age, I am not married, I have no children, I served in the army (although my military service consisted of removing snow and making the bed beautifully). Nowadays, it is not even necessary to serve a summons; it is enough to send it to the State Services - and the person is immediately deprived of the opportunity to leave the country. If I return to Russia, I will end up either in the army or in prison. Both options are tantamount to death.-Previously, Scandinavian countries have repeatedly refused political asylum to Russians. Thus, Russian Stanislav Brysin was refused asylum in Sweden, even despite his experience in holding protests and an open criminal case for -calls for terrorism.- At the beginning of the month, ASTRA wrote that in search of refuge, Brysin boarded a boat and sailed towards Ireland. Before this Sweden has deported a family from Belarus, against whom a criminal case has been opened in their homeland. The situation with shelters in the United States is no better. So, in material about American migration prisons ASTRA told the story of an opposition journalist from Russia with administrative punishment for -discrediting the army-, which US authorities deported to their homeland and handed over to the FSB.
